results.title: Man on the moon: epic journey of Apollo 11
results.creator_credit: Joel Banow, Philip Scheffler and Columbia Broadcasting System
results.brief_description: A report of the Apollo 11 mission to the Moon. Follows the progress of the various phases of the flight, including the landing of the lunar module, the first Moon walk by Neil Armstrong and Edwin Aldrin, and return to earth and splashdown in the Pacific.

results.title: Man on the moon: Apollo 11
results.creator_credit: Artransa Park Studios and National Aeronautics and Space Administration
results.brief_description: Shows details of the lunar surface from official footage recorded by the Apollo 11 spacecrew during the first manned moon landing on 20th July, 1969. Part of the 2 million feet of film made Public Domain by NASA. Silent film with English subtitles.

results.title: Man of tomorrow
results.creator_credit: David H. Villiers, Ronald H. Riley and Army Kinema Corporation
results.brief_description: Army training in leadership, given mainly at an “Outward Bound” school, where the emphasis is on character building rather than on traditional military training. The stories, humorously told, of a group of boys drawn from all Corps of the Army, who are seen following the various pursuits which fit them for leadership in Army careers.

results.title: Man looks at the moon
results.creator_credit: David MacDougall, Charles L. Finance and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: A study of the geology of the moon as surveyed by the naked eye, Galileo’s telescope, the largest telescopes, photography, spacecraft taking television pictures and finally, man actually on the moon collecting samples. Actual film shot on the moon is used extensively throughout. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Man is to man
results.creator_credit: Stanley Wright, Radio Tunis, Television Suisse and United Nations
results.brief_description: Describes the relief operation carried out jointly by trhe United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the League of Red Cross Societies on behalf of 200,000 Algerian refugees in Morocco and Tunisia. It is dedicated to all those who through their support made possible this humanitarian action. Commentary by Yul Brynner.

results.title: Man is a universe
results.creator_credit: Ronald Weyman, Nicholas Balla and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: This film reveals, in layman’s language, something of the progress made at the Montreal Neurological Institute in unravelling the mysteries of the human brain and nervous system. It shows some of the highly complex equipment used in neurological research and diagnosis, and follows a brain operation performed on an epileptic. Man’s brain and nervous system are, we see, a vast, unexplored universe about which much remains to be discovered.

results.title: Man is a builder
results.brief_description: Illustrates the important place held by the building industry in modern Britain, and the increasing demands being made for its service. Describes the men at craft, supervisory and executive levels, who are fulfilling the demands. Shows the training and skills they need, and some of the machines and methods they use.

results.title: Man in the peace tower
results.creator_credit: Roger Blais, Sydney Newman and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Robert Donnell is featured in his role of Dominion carilloneur at the Peace Tower in Ottawa. Interior views of the belfry with its bells, which range in weight from ten pounds to eleven tons, are shown.

results.title: Man in sports
results.brief_description: The imaginative use of camera gives remarkable fluidity to an international collection of photographs exhibited at the Baltimore Museum of Art in January 1968. The photographs emphasise the importance of sport as a common denominator among peoples and as a factor in human development to a fuller, more creative and enjoyable way of life.

results.title: Man in space
results.creator_credit: Ward Kimball and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: With an introduction by Walt Disney, this film depicts the development of rockets from the ancient Chinese weapons to modern missiles. Shows how humans may conquer outer space and establish a manned earth satellite. Presents the steps by which we will assault the space barrier and comments on the problems of “weightlessness” in outer space. Includes a clip from Georges Melies “Le Voyage a la lune”.
